awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Context Across Engineering Domains: Bridging the Eye-Mind Divide
awd_abstract_narration:
This research will identify the types of contexts, including pictures, sketches and diagrams, which are utilized in contemporary transportation and water resources engineering practice and in undergraduate engineering curricula.  The project will investigate the influence of the identified engineering problem contexts on students' and practicing engineers' performance in solving these problems and what they pay attention to during the solution process. While the problems are being solved, participants will be wearing a mobile eye-tracker and responding to questions about what they are doing. These two sets of data will be analyzed to determine how important different elements of the engineering problems are to arriving at solutions. With this knowledge engineering educators and researchers will be able to develop better materials that maximize the learning of engineering students, better preparing them to understand what kinds of contexts are used in authentic engineering practice.  

Developing situated or authentic engineering knowledge and ways of thinking in engineering students has been identified as a priority by the National Research Council, with the theoretically founded expectation that it will result in students who are more capable of innovative engineering design. Progress in this direction requires fundamental research on how contexts authentic to engineering practice influence cognition and learning in novices and experts, coupled with the design of research-based curriculum. The specific goals of this research are to synthesize novice and expert engineers' mental representations of transportation and hydraulics engineering concepts using an innovative research methodology combining (1) identification of engineering and academic contexts with practicing engineers and engineering faculty, (2) real time think-aloud interviews, (3) eye-tracking, and (4) reflective clinical interviews. This knowledge will further our understanding of critical elements of engineering problems and be used to develop new practices for the conduct of engineering education research and the thoughtful inclusion of context in newly developed engineering curricula.

por.por_cntn:
There is a lack of knowledge on the way transportation and hydraulic engineering practitioners and students use contextual representations (equations, graphs, and tables) that convey similar information about identical concepts to solve design problems. We attempted to answer the following specific questions: 1) What do the glance patterns of engineering students and practicing engineers look like? 2) What features of the problem do students and engineers report as important? To address these questions, we employed two data collection mechanisms: 1) eye-tracking to analyze visual attention and document problem-solving approaches and 2) reflective clinical interviews to analyze ways of thinking and document the reasons for problem-solving decisions that we refer to as rationales. The following items represent the major accomplishments of the research project:

  • The development of a robust methodology for studying engineering problem solving and contextual representations with eye tracking and reflective interviews.  
  • Development of the largest database (83 participants) of eye-tracking & interview design problem data collected and analyzed to date.
  • The identification and documentation of eight problem-solving rationales supported with both visual attention data and qualitative data.
  • Development of evidence that suggests students rely on their familiarity of a representation and how easy it is to use more so than other factors such as accuracy, time required to solve the problem, and simplicity when choosing a solution approach
  • The documentation of differences in problem solving between practicing engineers and engineering students, through the selection of contextual representations to solve the problems, the allocation of visual attention and the selection of problem solving rationales.
  • Training of 53 professors, post-docs, and PhD students in the topics of conceptual knowledge, situated cognition, and contextual representation, contextual learning, contextual problem solving, and the dissemination of robust authentically situated engineering design problems to those same participants.

If the educators trained in our workshops, adopt the design of transportation engineering and hydraulic engineering problems with a variety of contextual representations, those students who are exposed to more authentic engineering problems will be better prepared to enter the workforce and deliver robust engineering solutions.
